intro: Cerothamnus pensylvanicus, commonly known as Pennsylvania gilia, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and typically grows in open woodlands and rocky soils. The plant features slender, erect stems with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its showy, blue to purple flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant is generally herbaceous, though it may have some woody base in older specimens.
